abstract.p: Gish Jen article on being sick on vacation; photo (M)

block.p: My otherwise upstanding husband used to get sick the first day of every vacation. Now we have children: he can't get sick, so he doesn't. But in the olden days, he used to push and push work-wise, then take his temperature on the plane.
''You cannot be sick!'' I told him once. ''You haven't missed one day of work in five years. Why do you have to wait until we're on our way to Rome?''

My otherwise upstanding husband used to get sick the first day of every vacation. Now we have children: he can't get sick, so he doesn't. But in the olden days, he used to push and push work-wise, then take his temperature on the plane.
''You cannot be sick!'' I told him once. ''You haven't missed one day of work in five years. Why do you have to wait until we're on our way to Rome?''
He calmly squinted at the digital readout; ''101,'' he replied with not-so-secret satisfaction, and: ''Didn't you once do a paper on Florence Nightingale?''
''Do you remember how she never once told anyone they couldn't be sick?''
''How do you know?'' I said. ''You never did a paper on Florence Nightingale. Whereas I did, actually.''
There was an undulant pause here, such as explained our marriage.
''It was your first research paper, in fifth grade,'' he supplied sweetly -- adding, ''I think there is some Tylenol in the backpack.''

At last, at last, I realized that I could fall ill, too. Not with a stomach bug; stomach bugs are an affliction of no recreational value. However, to fall ill with something that renders you hammock-bound while other people concern themselves with your hydration is something else. To be ill is to be still and sentient; it is to be on vacation from yourself. You put down your guidebooks. You leave off making boring literary references. People enter your life, emanating interesting expertise.

I once ran a fever in the Caribbean (after my husband was done with his), and the impressions are still with me: the tough love of the hammock rope; the salt, close air; the sea-sensitive sky; the sex-crazed flowers. I knew every palm tree in the grove in which I hung -- which way they curved (which was every whichway); whether they had coconuts or not, and how many. They were my ward; they were my wards.

Sometimes I folded my hands across my chest. Sometimes I let them dangle, stretching my shoulder sockets. There was a double rainbow every day, waxing, waning, signifying nothing. Brilliant-colored birds braved my vicinity while my husband went water-skiing. He jumped waves like a man half his age, not like someone who ought to and probably would have his anterior cruciate ligaments repaired if only he could schedule the rehab.

My husband's vision has always been better than mine, but when I rose from my hammock, I was the one who saw everything: a moray eel in the reef, a ray with a flipper span of some five feet, a baby angel shark in the shallows. Hundreds of birds. I vowed to fall ill every vacation.

However, we have since had children. My job at the beach, besides making sure no one drowns, burns, chokes or is avoidably bitten, is supplies -- food, drink, shovels, pails, boogie boards, swim rings, Frisbees. Umbrellas, towels, chairs. Every now and then I look up at the sky, and there it is: healthy.
Gish Jen's most recent book is ''Who's Irish?''
